name: Social Working: An Analeptic Deck
description: An analeptic exploration of social working—not social work (the profession), but the verb: what communities, spirits, elements, and all beings have always done. Closing analysis in 'social work as profession' is already colonizing. Decolonizing means putting social work in a social working perspective. L4 'Social Working' contains: L3 'The Violent History' (Chapman & Withers' 40 names from professional social work); L3 'The Partnership Way' (Eisler's insight that the opposite of patriarchy isn't matriarchy but partnership—where ROLES survive, not names); L3 'Wicked History' (cultural memory that dwarfs the standard account—Jane Addams is a flat line on Google Trends while Wicked explodes); L3 'The Rest of the Worlds' (more-than-human social working: kingdoms, elements, epistemologies). All figures are complicit. The mainstream has never run clean.

sections.Reflection: What violences hide behind the names we are taught to honor?
sections.Description: Figures from the canonical social work history—the names taught in textbooks, celebrated in professional lore. All complicit in interlocking systems of oppression.

sections.Reflection: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?
sections.Description: Those systematically marginalized in social work historiography—truly erased, footnoted, or invisible. Their work preceded, paralleled, or challenged the 'standard account' but they don't appear in textbooks.

sections.Reflection: What parts of your heroes have been sanitized?
sections.Description: Highly visible figures whose complexity is hidden. MLK's radical economic critique is sanitized into 'I Have a Dream.' Gandhi's caste contradictions disappear. Malcolm X becomes a t-shirt. Chapman & Withers (28-29): 'We want Gandhi, Goldman, King, and Malcolm X to be celebrated for their important work... But celebrating their work isn't best facilitated by positioning them as always and only on the side of justice.'

sections.Reflection: What did your grandmother know that no institution taught?
sections.Description: Indigenous wisdom, spiritual practices, everyday roles—where something else lives. As Bayo Akomolafe says, 'Decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.'

sections.Reflection: What becomes possible when you stop trying to fix?
sections.Description: Those doing 'social working' differently today—through philosophy, podcasts, science communication, music. Not a clean alternative, but witnesses to the cracks.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers argue we should neither 'demonize nor romanticize' Addams—she was both radical AND complicit. 'Our point isn't that we should find another flawless historical figure to emulate' (46).
sections.Context: Hull-House founder, Nobel laureate, early NAACP member who spoke against lynching. Yet also 'called on governments to insist upon health certificates from the applicant for a marriage license' and was 'involved in plans to institutionalize women who had been labelled as feebleminded' (Chapman & Withers, 51). Seconded the 1912 presidential nomination of eugenicist Theodore Roosevelt.
sections.Reflection: What violences hide behind moral authority?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The Empress, The World

sections.Source: Of poor fathers she called 'married vagabonds': 'To treat the married vagabond as not responsible, is only to increase his irresponsibility' (32). The book argues she was liberal, not conservative—like 'most social work done today' (32).
sections.Context: Created 'scientific casework' to differentiate professional practice from volunteer work. Believed 'social conditions could be wonderfully improved if, to every family in distress, could be sent a volunteer visitor' (Chapman & Withers, 31). Though she grew up a poor orphan, 'much of Richmond's work denigrates poor people as morally reprehensible' (31).
sections.Reflection: When does structure become a cage?

sections.Source: Davis 'may well have tended towards the culturally determinist end of eugenic doctrine, but that doesn't place her outside of eugenics' (50). Worked with Addams in 'various social workings, including radical political struggles' (51).
sections.Context: Bedford Hills Reformatory superintendent. Chapman & Withers cite Nicole Rafter's work documenting Davis's 'central role in incarcerating women on eugenic grounds' (50). Close ally of Addams—'If Jane Addams were President, Katharine Davis would be her Vice President' (51).
sections.Reflection: What fears drive policies that claim to be rational?

sections.Source: 'A social Darwinist organizer of the COS movement, Lowell believed that poverty had its roots in the character of the poor. Pauperism would be eliminated by educating and rehabilitating the poor' rather than through relief (52).
sections.Context: 'Founder of the New York City Charity Organization Society' (52) and close Addams ally through the Anti-Imperialist League and National Consumers League. Rafter documents her 'central role in advancing eugenic criminology policies' that have been 'downplayed or erased in accounts of her life' (50).
sections.Reflection: How do we reckon with those who did both harm and good?

sections.Source: 'A great general has said that the only good Indian is a dead one… In a sense, I agree with the sentiment, but only in this: that all the Indian there is in the race should be dead. Kill the Indian in him, and save the man' (60).
sections.Context: Founded Carlisle Indian Industrial School, 'the first of its kind' (60). Spoke at the 1892 National Conference on Charities and Corrections—the organization that 'directly became legitimized professional social work' (60).
sections.Reflection: What bondage presents itself as education?

sections.Source: Rose claimed Africville residents were 'ready and to some extent eager to negotiate a settlement.' Chapman & Withers note: 'It wasn't true that people welcomed the relocation; many were adamantly opposed to it' (70). Rose received the Canadian Centennial Medal in 1967, 'during the time of active destruction' (70).
sections.Context: Director of University of Toronto School of Social Work; president of Canadian Association of Social Workers. 'The driving force behind the construction of Canada's first major low-rent rehousing project, Regent Park' (62). In 1963, 'visited Africville for two hours' and wrote a report justifying the relocation (69).
sections.Reflection: What dies when experts decide communities must be 'renewed'?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (28): "Radical iterations of the standard account of social work history follow a pat tern often found in radical analysis...."
sections.Context: Professionalization of medicine and social work. Racist medical models.
sections.Reflection: Who decides what counts as professional knowledge?
sections.Key Insight: Professionalization
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The Emperor, Wheel of Fortune

sections.Source: McCulloch compared a poor family to 'a crustacean which has left the free, independent life common to its family, and is living as a parasite, or pauper' (35). His answer to 'What can we do?': 'First, we must close up official out-door relief. Second, we must check private and indiscriminate benevolence… Third, we must get hold of the children' (35).
sections.Context: Founder and leader of the Indianapolis COS. Published 'The Tribe of Ishmael: A Study in Social Degradation' at the 1888 National Conference of Charities and Corrections (35). 'One of the earliest to instill fear in the general public about both indiscriminate relief and the eugenic threat that poor, disabled, and racialized people posed' (35).
sections.Reflection: What cycles of harm continue from research done with good intentions?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: Wheel of Fortune, The Moon, The Hanged Man

sections.Source: Part of the broader COS campaign: McCulloch's answer to 'What can we do?' included 'Third, we must get hold of the children' (35). Child apprehension emerged alongside eugenic reasoning about preventing 'unfit' reproduction.
sections.Context: 'An architect of Canada's Children's Aid Society system' (35). Nancy Christie documents how 'Kelso aimed to convert as many Catholic children to Protestantism as possible. This practice was articulated as motivated by concern for the child' (35).
sections.Reflection: Whose children are 'saved'? From what? For whom?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Chariot, The Fool, The Emperor

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (43): 'According to this origin story, Brackett came up with the term to imply that the new profession was "orderly, responsible, and disciplined"—exactly what liberals normatively say of the innovations of early social work.'
sections.Context: Credited with coining the term 'social work' in the early 1900s. 'He added the word work to differentiate professional practice from what he considered the often misguided and self-serving philanthropic activity of wealthy volunteers' (Chapman & Withers, 43).
sections.Reflection: What is named into existence? What is named out?
sections.Key Insight: The naming itself was an act of power—separating 'professional' (legitimate) from 'volunteer' (misguided). Who gets to define what counts as real work?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (43-44): Unlike Brackett's COS-aligned version, Patten's term 'describes both COS and settlement workers, and is coined by someone who prefers the more politicized work of the settlement movement.'
sections.Context: Alternative origin story: credited with coining 'social worker.' Advocated consumption education for poor people. 'Organised leisure time would facilitate access for the poor to the "right" activities including daily consumption' (Chapman & Withers, 48).
sections.Reflection: Who teaches whom how to live?
sections.Key Insight: Two origin stories, two visions: Brackett's 'orderly, disciplined' professionalism vs. Patten's 'politicized' settlement work. The term's meaning was contested from birth.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (60): "professed certain racist values and ideas tends to be omitted from the standard  account of Addams’s interventions into the social world...."
sections.Context: Chaired the 1892 conference where Pratt spoke. Nearly invisible now.
sections.Reflection: What world was built on erased foundations?
sections.Key Insight: Conference Chairman
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The World, The Emperor, The Hierophant

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (47): Addams seconded his nomination despite his eugenics. The 'Progressive' label hid the eugenic core—progress for whom?
sections.Context: Eugenicist president whose 1912 Progressive Party nomination Jane Addams seconded. 'Vice President Roosevelt became president in 1901 after McKinley was assassinated... made an unsuccessful run for the presidency in 1912, representing the Progressive Party, which he'd founded' (Chapman & Withers, 47).
sections.Reflection: What does 'progress' require? Whose bodies?
sections.Key Insight: Addams—celebrated progressive, early NAACP member—seconded a eugenicist's nomination. This is the 'neither demonize nor romanticize' point made flesh.

sections.Source: 'Eugenic framings of 'fitness' were those characteristics already long exalted within moral economies of human value; those considered unfit were diverse members of oppressed groups' (35).
sections.Context: 'First articulated eugenic doctrine in 1865 and later coined the actual word in 1883' (34). 'Eugenics became an incredibly popular ideology in which those considered 'fit' were encouraged to reproduce while those considered 'unfit' were discouraged from reproducing' (34).
sections.Reflection: What words do we coin that will be condemned?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Devil, Wheel of Fortune

sections.Quote: Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.
sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (67-70): "ing the violences of poverty and racism, various schemes are put in place to  teach poor and racialized people to live more like the white ruling classes...."
sections.Context: 'Sometimes people need to be shown what's in their best interests.'
sections.Reflection: Who decides what's best for whom?
sections.Key Insight: Paternalism

sections.Source: 'To keep them in comfortable quarters and allow them to live in idleness is not the way to get rid of them. Hard work and strict discipline… [are] the best means of getting rid of the professional vagrant' (34). A report summarizing his statement called poor people an 'army of tramps that infest this Province' (34).
sections.Context: Representing Toronto's Associated Charities (COS), Baldwin 'clearly articulated the movement's drive to eradicate poor people' (34).
sections.Reflection: What would it mean to 'get rid of' poverty without getting rid of the poor?

sections.Source: The book argues this complicates the idea that anyone can be 'always and only aligned with justice and the oppressed' (29). Goldman should be 'celebrated for [her] important work... But celebrating [her] work isn't best facilitated by positioning [her] as always and only on the side of justice' (28-29).
sections.Context: Anarchist revolutionary. Chapman & Withers note that 'a number of socialist and anarchist social justice activists, including Emma Goldman, were eugenicists' (28). Part of their argument that 'liberals and radicals alike, whether Marxist, feminist, anarchist, or other, tended to work for eugenic aims a century ago' (38).
sections.Reflection: What blind spots hide in our most radical visions?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers note: 'We can just pause to consider what gets included or excluded in normative social work history' (60). Wells critiqued Booker T. Washington's assimilative measures alongside W.E.B. Du Bois (48).
sections.Context: 'Black anti-lynching activist and social worker' (60). In 1892—the same year Pratt spoke at the National Conference on Charities and Corrections—Wells 'published Southern Horrors: Lynch Law in All Its Phases, which is a very different kind of social working than that of McCulloch or Pratt' (60).
sections.Reflection: What truth requires courage to speak in your context?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (48): Du Bois and Wells represented a radical alternative to Washington's accommodation—but were 'political allies of Addams' despite her own contradictions.
sections.Context: NAACP co-founder. Along with Ida B. Wells, critiqued Booker T. Washington's 'assimilative measures, aimed at integrating poor people into ruling class values and mores' (Chapman & Withers, 48).
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to work within institutions you're critiquing?
sections.Key Insight: The Du Bois-Washington debate prefigured later tensions: accommodation vs. confrontation, working within systems vs. building alternatives. Both were 'erased' from mainstream social work history.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Hermit, The Star

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2, 74-75): Walker and the Independent Order of St. Luke 'led a streetcar boycott against racial segregation in 1903'—one of many acts of resistance that built the infrastructure for later movements.
sections.Context: First woman bank president in America (1903). Founded St. Luke Penny Savings Bank for Black community financial autonomy. Also led a streetcar boycott against racial segregation in Richmond, Virginia.
sections.Reflection: What resources do you have that systems refuse to recognize?
sections.Key Insight: Walker's bank and boycotts were 'newcomer settlement social work'—but routinely left out of credit union and social work history. Financial autonomy as resistance.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers: The 'standard account' centers Anglo-American secular social work. Al-Ghazali represents a tradition of Islamic community care that predates and parallels Western models but is invisible in textbooks.
sections.Context: Founded Society of Muslim Ladies in Egypt (1936). Imprisoned and tortured by Nasser regime for organizing. Represents global, non-secular tradition of community care that the 'standard account' ignores.
sections.Reflection: What becomes visible only from a position of surrender?
sections.Key Insight: Global community care traditions exist outside the Anglo-American secular frame—but are erased from 'social work history.'
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hanged Man, Strength, The High Priestess

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Barrett's settlement is routinely left out of social work history. Chapter 2 documents how 'white social work history' erases Black settlement houses that were doing the same work—or earlier.
sections.Context: Founded Locust Street Settlement in Hampton, Virginia (1890)—possibly predating Hull House's breadth of services. Started in her own home, grew to community center serving Black families.
sections.Reflection: What grows from care that refuses institutional recognition?
sections.Key Insight: Locust Street Settlement may have predated some of Addams's services, yet Barrett is rarely credited in 'standard account' textbooks.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The Star, The Magician

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Documents how Black women's media activism—community organizing through journalism—was a form of 'social working' that predated and paralleled white settlement houses.
sections.Context: First Black woman newspaper editor in North America. Published Provincial Freeman in Canada, advocating for fugitive slaves and integration. Lawyer, educator, abolitionist.
sections.Reflection: What hope sustains when the journey has no guaranteed end?
sections.Key Insight: Shadd Cary's journalism was mutual aid through media—creating community, sharing resources, building networks for fugitives. This is social work history that textbooks erase.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Star, The Chariot, The Magician

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Haynes built Black social work education while white institutions excluded Black students. The 'standard account' credits white founders while erasing those who trained generations of Black practitioners.
sections.Context: First Black person to earn PhD from Columbia (1912). Co-founded National Urban League. Created the first training program for Black social workers at Fisk University.
sections.Reflection: Can justice be built within unjust institutions?
sections.Key Insight: Haynes founded institutions to train Black social workers because white schools wouldn't. This parallel infrastructure is invisible in 'social work history.'

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Ransom's Institutional Church was doing settlement work contemporaneous with Hull House—but from a Black church tradition. The 'standard account' credits Addams while erasing Ransom.
sections.Context: AME Bishop who founded Institutional Church in Chicago (1900)—combining worship with social services, employment bureau, kindergarten. Christian socialist who brought social gospel to Black churches.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom comes from standing apart from mainstream success?
sections.Key Insight: The Black church as social work institution predates secular white settlement houses—but this history is invisible in textbooks.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Bibb's work with fugitive settlements represents 'newcomer settlement social work'—mutual aid among the displaced—that predates white settlement houses but carries 'colonizer contradiction' in its land claims.
sections.Context: Escaped slavery multiple times trying to free his family. Founded Voice of the Fugitive newspaper in Canada. Helped build fugitive settlements—mutual aid communities for escaped slaves.
sections.Reflection: What would you risk everything to return to?
sections.Key Insight: Fugitive settlements were doing 'settlement work' before Jane Addams—but this complicates the narrative because they also displaced Indigenous peoples. All are complicit.
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Lovers, The Chariot, The Fool

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (48): Washington's approach represented one pole of Black anti-racist strategy—work within the system, build institutions, accommodate to survive. Du Bois and Wells represented another.
sections.Context: Accommodation politics. Advocated 'assimilative measures, aimed at integrating poor people into ruling class values and mores' (Chapman & Withers, 48). Critiqued by W.E.B. Du Bois and Ida B. Wells.
sections.Reflection: When is patience wisdom? When is it collaboration?
sections.Key Insight: The Washington-Du Bois debate isn't just historical—it's the perennial question: work within broken systems or build alternatives? Both strategies have costs; both have been used by those in power to divide movements.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers: Douglass represents the erasure of Black leadership from 'social work history.' His organizing, mutual aid networks, and community building were 'social working' before the term existed.
sections.Context: Self-liberated, self-educated, self-made. Escaped slavery, became leading abolitionist orator. Supported women's suffrage—rare among men of his era. His autobiography was act of resistance.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to make yourself when the world unmakes you?
sections.Key Insight: Douglass's work—speaking tours, newspapers, mutual aid—was community organizing and social change work. But because it wasn't in white settlement houses, it's not called 'social work.'

sections.Source: Angela Davis reminds us 'we shouldn't remember these histories through the lens of individualism. Bus boycotts could have been mobilized around Colvin's arrest' (74). The movement was 'built on painstaking organizing efforts and the infrastructure' of collective action (75).
sections.Context: 'Nine months before Rosa Parks made her famous stand... Claudette Colvin... refused to move from her seat on a bus' (73-74). Chapman & Withers discuss how movement leaders decided 'she was not the right person to symbolically galvanize a mass movement' (74).
sections.Reflection: Whose determination is remembered? Whose is erased?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (74-75): 'Like all social justice movements, the Montgomery bus boycott was built on painstaking organizing efforts and the infrastructure developed through these efforts by generations of people struggling for social justice. The bus boycott wasn't a spontaneous explosion.'
sections.Context: Trained NAACP organizer who attended Highlander Folk School. Not 'just tired'—strategically chosen to re-stage what Claudette Colvin had done nine months earlier. Movement leaders decided Colvin 'was not the right person to symbolically galvanize a mass movement' (Chapman & Withers, 74).
sections.Reflection: What gets remembered as spontaneous that was actually organized?
sections.Key Insight: Angela Davis: 'We shouldn't remember these histories through the lens of individualism' (74). The movement needed both the infrastructure AND the symbolic spark.

sections.Source: Now on the Canadian $10 bill—but Chapman & Withers use her story to show how Canadian 'national mythology' claims Canada is 'not a racist country, or at least less so than our southern neighbour,' which 'is untrue' (67).
sections.Context: 'Often referred to as Canada's Rosa Parks, was jailed and eventually fined after sitting in a section reserved for whites in the Roseland,' a movie theatre in New Glasgow, Nova Scotia (74). 'A decade before Colvin and Parks wouldn't move from their seats in Alabama' (74).
sections.Reflection: What joy is an act of resistance?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers describe how 'many people in Africville were against relocation and the destruction of their community,' contrary to Rose's claims that residents were 'ready and to some extent eager' (70).
sections.Context: 'The relocations took place from 1964 to 1967, with the final holdout, 'Pa' Carvery, vacating his home in 1970' (70). While Albert Rose received medals, Carvery held his ground.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to hold ground when the world insists you move?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (Chapter 2): Shreve represents the most invisible layer—not only erased as a Black woman doing community care, but invisible even within the recovery of erased voices.
sections.Context: Circuit-riding missionary serving the Buxton fugitive settlement in Canada. Sister of Mary Ann Shadd Cary. Nearly invisible to history—even within the erasure of Black social workers.
sections.Reflection: Whose knowledge sustains communities while remaining unwritten?
sections.Key Insight: If Ida B. Wells is footnoted and Mary Ann Shadd Cary is nearly forgotten, Shreve is truly invisible. How many layers of erasure exist?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Star, The Hermit

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers' framework of 'interlocking oppressions' applies: Rustin was erased not for lack of contribution but because homophobia intersected with anti-Black racism. He did the work; others got the credit.
sections.Context: Chief organizer of the 1963 March on Washington. Deliberately marginalized within the movement for being openly gay. Pacifist who trained MLK in nonviolent tactics.
sections.Reflection: What work happens behind the scenes? Who gets credited?
sections.Key Insight: Rustin organized the most famous civil rights event in history—but was hidden because of who he loved. This is 'interlocking oppression' in the movement itself.

sections.Quote: Not everything that is faced can be changed, but nothing can be changed until it is faced.
sections.Source: Chapman & Withers' framework: Baldwin represents those who did 'social working' through testimony and truth-telling. His witness—naming what America refused to face—was a form of care.
sections.Context: Writer, witness, exile. Left America to survive. Returned to testify. Gay, Black, unflinching—and therefore erased from mainstream civil rights narratives.
sections.Reflection: What are you refusing to face?
sections.Key Insight: Witness

sections.Source: The FBI called the Free Breakfast Program 'the greatest threat to internal security.' This was social work—meeting immediate needs—but framed as terrorism because it built Black community power.
sections.Context: Co-founded Black Panther Party. Created Free Breakfast for Children—the model for federal school breakfast programs. Also free health clinics, schools, pest control. 'Survival pending revolution.'
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to feed people as an act of revolution?
sections.Key Insight: The Panthers did what settlement houses claimed to do—feed children, provide healthcare, build community—but were criminalized for it. Same work, different bodies, different response.

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (68): "In one side, we will represent a decolonial account of social work that is colonial in itself because it leaves aside the indigeneous account...."
sections.Context: Transformation upon transformation. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
sections.Reflection: What would it mean to change your mind completely?
sections.Key Insight: Killed Before Africville Emptied

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (68): "ably both of these radicalization stories are factual, and both were surely sig nificant...."
sections.Context: The sanitized dream vs. the radical reality. Assassinated before Africville was emptied.
sections.Reflection: What parts of your heroes have been sanitized?
sections.Key Insight: Sanitized Legacy

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers (28-29): "ably both of these radicalization stories are factual, and both were surely sig nificant...."
sections.Context: Troubling relationship with 'untouchable' caste. Contradictions.
sections.Reflection: What contradictions do our heroes carry?
sections.Key Insight: Contradictions
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, Temperance, The Hanged Man

sections.Source:
Chapman & Withers (28): "28 Deconstructing Social Work and Social Work History 
is moving in the water...."
sections.Context: The river crossing metaphor. Symbolic radicalization. Icon on t-shirts.
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to 'cross to the other side' when there is no other side?
sections.Key Insight: Crossing The River

sections.Quote: Decolonization might be more about grandmothers.
sections.Context: As Bayo Akomolafe says, decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.
sections.Reflection: What did your grandmother know that no institution taught?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The High Priestess, The World

sections.Context: The work that holds the world together. Never counted in GDP.
sections.Reflection: What labor is invisible because it is constant?

sections.Context: The one who shows up. No professional boundary. No billing code.
sections.Reflection: Who shows up for you without being paid?

sections.Context: Holding space at thresholds. Birth and death doulas. The ancient role.
sections.Reflection: Who holds space for you at thresholds?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The High Priestess, Strength

sections.Context: Spirit of enslaved African elders in Umbanda. Slow wisdom. Pipe smoke. Patience earned through suffering.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom comes only through suffering that should never have been?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The Hierophant, The High Priestess

sections.Context: Indigenous ancestral spirits in Umbanda. Warriors and healers. The forest's knowledge.
sections.Reflection: What knowledge lives in the land that was stolen?

items.name: Pai de Santo / Mãe de Santo

sections.Context: Father/Mother of the saints. Keeper of Axé. Community anchor.
sections.Reflection: What communities anchor you that no institution recognizes?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The High Priestess, The Magician

sections.Context: The ethics Addams admired in poor communities: 'the ready outflow of sympathy and material assistance.'
sections.Reflection: When did someone just show up with what you needed?

sections.Context: The one who asks the obvious question that no one else will ask.
sections.Reflection: What obvious question are you afraid to ask?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Star, The Sun

sections.Quote: The times are urgent; let us slow down.
sections.Context: 'The times are urgent; let us slow down.' Nigerian philosopher, psychologist, professor.
sections.Reflection: What becomes possible when you stop trying to fix?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Hermit, The High Priestess

sections.Context: Hospicing modernity. 'We cannot continue to consume the world and expect different results.'
sections.Reflection: What needs to die so something else can live?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Tower, The Hermit

sections.Context: The Emerald podcast. Remembering what was almost forgotten. Ancestral practices.
sections.Reflection: What have you almost forgotten that wants to be remembered?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The High Priestess, The Magician

sections.Context: Bringing meditation to secular spaces. Also: contradictions and controversies.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom traditions get extracted and repackaged?

sections.Context: Making science accessible. Wonder as public education.
sections.Reflection: What knowledge do you make accessible? What do you gatekeep?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Star, The Magician, The Sun

sections.Context: Brazilian artist weaving ancestral wisdom through contemporary sound.
sections.Reflection: What ancestral wisdom moves through your art, your work, your body?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Star, The Empress

sections.Source: Two Aberdeen Saturday Pioneer editorials (1890) advocated 'the total annihilation of the few remaining Indians' after Wounded Knee.
sections.Context: The Wonderful Wizard of Oz (1900). Created the canonical American fairy tale. Also wrote editorials calling for the extermination of Native Americans.
sections.Reflection: What genocides hide behind our beloved stories?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Fool, The World

sections.Source: The studio system that created 'Somewhere Over the Rainbow' also destroyed the girl who sang it.
sections.Context: Dorothy in the 1939 film. MGM fed her amphetamines to control her weight and barbiturates to sleep. Dead at 47.
sections.Reflection: What does the rainbow cost the one who sings it?

sections.Source: The Wiz reimagined Kansas as Harlem, the Yellow Brick Road as Black cultural expression. 7 Tony Awards. Then erasure.
sections.Context: Composer/lyricist of The Wiz (1975). Won the Tony for Best Original Score. 'Ease on Down the Road.' Died in 1987, largely forgotten.
sections.Reflection: What Black genius is celebrated then forgotten?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Wheel of Fortune, The Hermit

sections.Context: Dorothy in The Wiz film (1978). A 33-year-old playing a 24-year-old schoolteacher. Motown royalty crossing to cinema.
sections.Reflection: Who gets to reimagine themselves?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The Star, The Chariot

sections.Source: The Scarecrow who needed a brain became the King of Pop. Also: allegations, contradictions, tragedy.
sections.Context: Scarecrow in The Wiz (1978). 19 years old. Met Quincy Jones on set—beginning the collaboration that made Thriller.
sections.Reflection: What transformation costs everything?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Star, The Moon

sections.Context: Musical director of The Wiz film (1978). The collaboration with Michael Jackson that began here led to Off the Wall, Thriller, Bad.
sections.Reflection: What connections create new worlds?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Emperor, The World

sections.Source: 'People are so rarely what they seem.' The moral: wickedness is constructed by those in power.
sections.Context: Wicked: The Life and Times of the Wicked Witch of the West (1995). Told the story from the 'villain's' perspective. Elphaba wasn't wicked—she was green, different, fighting oppression.
sections.Reflection: Whose perspective makes the villain?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The High Priestess, Justice

sections.Context: Composer/lyricist of Wicked the musical (2003). Also Godspell, Pippin, Pocahontas, Prince of Egypt. 'Defying Gravity.'
sections.Reflection: What does it mean to defy gravity?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Magician, The Star, The Chariot

sections.Source: From Wicked Witch to Snow Queen—both stories about women called monstrous for their power.
sections.Context: Original Elphaba (2003). The voice that made 'Defying Gravity' an anthem. Later: Elsa in Frozen. 'Let It Go.'
sections.Reflection: What power gets called monstrous?

sections.Context: All beings that move, eat, breathe, feel. Social working predates humans by hundreds of millions of years. Ant colonies. Wolf packs. Elephant grief.
sections.Reflection: What social working did animals teach us that we forgot?

sections.Source: Suzanne Simard: 'A forest is a cooperative system.'
sections.Context: The Wood Wide Web. Trees share nutrients through fungal networks. Mother trees feed their seedlings. Plants warn each other of predators.
sections.Reflection: What do the trees know about mutual aid?

sections.Context: Stone, crystal, metal, earth. The bones of the planet. Time scales that make human history a blink.
sections.Reflection: What does the mountain know about patience?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Emperor, The World, The Hermit

sections.Source: Merlin Sheldrake: 'Fungi make worlds. They also unmake them.'
sections.Context: Neither plant nor animal. The decomposers. The connectors. Mycelium networks that make forests possible. Psychedelics that dissolve ego.
sections.Reflection: What needs to decompose so something else can live?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, Death, The Magician

sections.Source: Spivak: 'The mainstream has never run clean.'
sections.Context: Flows, adapts, erodes, sustains. 60% of your body. The element of emotion, intuition, the unconscious.
sections.Reflection: What flows through you that you cannot control?

sections.Context: Transforms, destroys, warms, illuminates. The element of will, passion, action. Some ecosystems need fire to regenerate.
sections.Reflection: What needs to burn so something else can grow?

sections.Context: Breath, wind, thought, communication. Invisible but essential. The element of mind, ideas, connection across distance.
sections.Reflection: What ideas carry on the wind?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Fool, The Magician, The Star

sections.Context: Ground, body, matter, stability. The element of manifestation, the physical, the practical. What we stand on.
sections.Reflection: What ground do you stand on? Whose ground is it?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The Emperor, The World

sections.Context: The immaterial. Consciousness, soul, the animating principle. What religions try to name and science tries to ignore.
sections.Reflection: What is the part of you that cannot be measured?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Hermit, The World

sections.Context: The material. Atoms, mass, the physical universe. What science can measure. What breaks down.
sections.Reflection: What is the part of you that will return to dust?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Emperor, The Devil, The World

sections.Context: The epistemology of measurement, experiment, falsification. Powerful. Also: colonial, extractive, often weaponized.
sections.Reflection: What can science see? What is it blind to?

sections.Context: The epistemology of revelation, tradition, faith. Meaning-making. Community. Also: dogma, violence, control.
sections.Reflection: What can religion see? What is it blind to?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hierophant, The High Priestess, Judgement

sections.Source: Palmares at its height had 20,000+ residents across multiple villages. Zumbi led guerrilla resistance for 15 years after the main quilombo fell. Captured and beheaded; his head displayed in public to 'prove he was not immortal.'
sections.Context: Last leader of Quilombo dos Palmares (1655-1695), the largest maroon settlement in the Americas. For nearly a century, Palmares resisted Portuguese colonizers—a self-organized community of escaped enslaved Africans and Indigenous peoples practicing mutual aid, collective governance, and armed resistance.
sections.Reflection: What freedom was built 200 years before Hull House that history erased?

sections.Source: Population estimates range from 10,000 to 30,000 across multiple villages. Practiced African-derived agriculture, governance, and spirituality. Resisted Portuguese military expeditions for nine decades.
sections.Context: The first large-scale settlement of care in the Americas (1605-1694). Self-organized community of escaped enslaved Africans, Indigenous peoples, and others fleeing colonial violence. Collective farming, shared governance, spiritual practices. Nearly 200 years before Hull House.
sections.Reflection: What if the first 'settlement house' was built by those escaping enslavement?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Tower, The Star, The World

sections.Source: Samuel Barnett: 'The poor need not money but friendship.' Named after Arnold Toynbee, who died at 30 after working himself to exhaustion in service to the poor.
sections.Context: London, 1884. The model for all settlement houses. Jane Addams visited here before founding Hull House. Where university students lived alongside the poor to 'learn from' them—though the paternalism was embedded from the start.
sections.Reflection: What was generous in this model? What was condescending?

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers: 'We should neither demonize nor romanticize Addams' (46). Hull House did real good AND participated in interlocking systems of oppression.
sections.Context: Chicago, 1889. Jane Addams and Ellen Gates Starr. The most famous American settlement. Kindergarten, English classes, arts programs. Also: eugenic health screenings, marriage certificate requirements, complicity.
sections.Reflection: Can a place do both harm and good? What does that mean?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Empress, The Hierophant, The Tower

sections.Source: Myles Horton: 'We don't teach people. We help them learn.' The FBI tried to shut it down; the state seized the property in 1961.
sections.Context: Tennessee, 1932. Where Rosa Parks trained before Montgomery. Where MLK, John Lewis, and countless civil rights organizers learned. Desegregated decades before the law required it.
sections.Reflection: What happens when a place teaches what the state forbids?

sections.Source: Curriculum asked: 'What do we mean by freedom?' Three civil rights workers—Chaney, Goodman, Schwerner—murdered that summer.
sections.Context: Mississippi, 1964. Freedom Summer. 41 schools, 2,000+ students. Black history, constitutional rights, leadership. Education as liberation while registering voters.
sections.Reflection: What education is worth dying for?

sections.Source: Huey Newton: 'Survival pending revolution.' The FBI called the Free Breakfast Program 'the greatest threat to internal security.'
sections.Context: Oakland and nationwide, 1966-1980s. Free breakfast for children. Free health clinics. Free ambulance services. Free shoes. Free pest control. Revolution through meeting immediate needs.
sections.Reflection: What if feeding children is more revolutionary than rhetoric?

sections.Source: During COVID, terreiros fed communities when government failed. Centuries of criminalization couldn't stop them.
sections.Context: Brazil, ongoing. Candomblé and Umbanda temples. Community centers where Axé flows. Food, healing, belonging, justice. Often in the poorest neighborhoods, doing what the state refuses.
sections.Reflection: What care continues despite centuries of criminalization?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The High Priestess, The Empress, The World

sections.Source: Dorothy Day: 'The Gospel takes away our right to discriminate between the deserving and the undeserving poor.'
sections.Context: New York and worldwide, 1933-present. Dorothy Day and Peter Maurin. Hospitality houses, soup kitchens, farms. Voluntary poverty. Anarchism meets Catholicism.
sections.Reflection: What if you gave up the right to judge who deserves help?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Hermit, The Empress, The Fool

sections.Source: The word 'maroon' comes from Spanish 'cimarrón'—wild, untamed. Freedom required wildness.
sections.Context: Throughout the Americas, 1500s-present. Jamaica (Accompong), Suriname (Saramaka, Ndyuka), Florida (Black Seminoles), Brazil (quilombos). Self-liberated people building freedom in hostile territory.
sections.Reflection: What freedom can only be built by running away?
sections.Archetypal Resonances: The Chariot, The Tower, The Star

sections.Source: Chapman & Withers: Albert Rose visited for 'two hours' and wrote the report justifying destruction (69). Pa Carvery held out until 1970.
sections.Context: Halifax, Nova Scotia, 1848-1970. Black community destroyed by 'urban renewal.' Denied city services for decades, then demolished for being a 'slum.' Residents relocated in garbage trucks.
sections.Reflection: What communities have been destroyed in the name of improvement?
What places in your life have been sites of care? Which were destroyed?
sections.Description: Places where social working happened: Quilombo dos Palmares (1605), Toynbee Hall (1884), Hull House (1889), Highlander Folk School (1932), Freedom Schools (1964), Black Panther programs (1966), Terreiros (ongoing), Catholic Worker houses (1933), Maroon communities (throughout), and Africville (destroyed 1970). Some were built by professionals; most by those escaping oppression.

sections.Reflection: What genocides hide behind our beloved stories?
sections.Description: The canonical American fairy tale (1900/1939). The 'standard account' of Oz—white Kansas girl's journey. Beloved. Also: written by a man who called for Native genocide.

sections.Reflection: What Black genius is celebrated then erased?
sections.Description: Black cultural reimagining (1975/1978). Kansas becomes Harlem. Yellow Brick Road becomes 'Ease on Down.' 7 Tony Awards. Then the composer dies forgotten.

sections.Reflection: What if the villain was right all along—and what's lost when we make that message palatable?
sections.Description: The sanitized merger (1995/2003). Wicked shifts race → color (green), making oppression 'digestible' for wider audiences. The Wiz was explicit about Blackness; Wicked encodes the same othering but in a way that lets white audiences feel comfortable. 'No one is born wicked'—but also, no one has to confront actual racism.
sections.Key Insight: Wicked is the colonial compromise: keeps the message about vilification of the 'other,' but removes the specificity that would make white audiences uncomfortable. Green is safer than Black.

sections.Reflection: What did the other kingdoms know before we forgot?
sections.Description: Animal, Plant, Mineral, Fungi. The more-than-human worlds that were social working before humans existed. Cooperation, decomposition, deep time.

sections.Reflection: What element are you avoiding?
sections.Description: Water, Fire, Air, Earth. The classical elements that predate chemistry. Metaphors for aspects of existence that science alone cannot capture.

sections.Reflection: What would it mean to stop dividing spirit from matter?
sections.Description: Spirit and Matter—the split that defines Western metaphysics. But what if they were never separate? What if the split itself is the problem?

sections.Reflection: What can neither science nor religion alone understand?
sections.Description: Science and Religion—two ways of knowing, each blind to what the other sees. Both have been weapons. Both have been medicine.

sections.Source: Eisler: in partnership societies, roles survived, not names. The Grandmother, not a specific grandmother.
sections.Reflection: What wisdom lives in roles rather than names?
sections.Description: Afro-Brazilian spiritual tradition. Ancestral spirits—Preto Velho (enslaved elders), Caboclo (Indigenous spirits). ROLES, not named individuals. What partnership societies preserved.

sections.Source: Eisler's insight: in partnership societies, individual names didn't survive—only ROLES. The Chalice and the Blade.
sections.Reflection: What role are you playing that no institution recognizes?
sections.Description: The roles that do social working without credentials: Grandmother, Mother, Friend, Doula, Neighbor, Child. As Bayo Akomolafe says: 'Decolonization might be more about grandmothers than about systems.'

sections.Source: A Violent History of Benevolence (2019): 'The mainstream has never run clean.' Also: 'We should neither demonize nor romanticize' any of these figures.
sections.Reflection: What violences hide behind the profession's origin story?
sections.Description: Chapman & Withers' names: the Standard Account (Jane Addams, Mary Richmond), the truly Erased (Ida B. Wells, Claudette Colvin), and the Sanitized Icons (MLK, Gandhi—visible but their complexity hidden). Professional social work history—complicit figures, all.

sections.Source: Riane Eisler (1987): dominator vs. partnership models. The chalice (partnership) vs. the blade (domination). Places where partnership was practiced.
sections.Reflection: What would social working look like without named heroes—but with remembered places?
sections.Description: Eisler's insight from The Chalice and the Blade: the opposite of patriarchy isn't matriarchy—it's partnership (gylany). In partnership societies, ROLES survived, not names. The Grandmother, not Jane Addams. And PLACES of care—Quilombo dos Palmares (1605) predates Hull House by nearly 200 years.

sections.Source: Google Trends data shows what matters: MLK spikes annually, Wicked peaks in 2024, Jane Addams barely registers.
sections.Reflection: What if cultural memory is more honest than academic history?
sections.Description: Cultural memory that dwarfs the standard account. Google Trends: Jane Addams is a flat line; Wicked explodes. The Oz-to-Wiz-to-Wicked arc: canonical story → Black reimagining → sanitized merger. What actually lives in collective imagination.

sections.Reflection: What would it mean to learn social working from fungi?
sections.Description: More-than-human and beyond-profession social working. The Kingdoms (Animal, Plant, Mineral, Fungi), The Elements (Water, Fire, Air, Earth), Non-Duality (Spirit/Matter), Epistemologies (Science/Religion), and Contemporary Witnesses who point beyond the colonial frame. Social working was happening for billions of years before humans named it.

sections.Source: Analepsis: from Chapman & Withers' call for 'a persistent dredging operation' of history. The mainstream has never run clean, perhaps never can.
sections.Reflection: What if everyone and everything is always already social working?
sections.Description: Not social work (noun, profession, colonial)—social working (verb, what all beings do). Closing analysis in 'social work as profession' is already colonizing. Decolonizing means putting social work in a social working perspective. This deck is an analeptic exploration: holding contradictions without resolving them, dredging the mainstream that has never run clean.
